channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Ten days into the war, Russia’s continued shelling near protected escape routes for Ukrainian civilians has made clear that President Vladimir Putin has decided to hammer civilian infrastructure and pulverize basic services in a sustained assault. https://t.co/1fEuk3Z0lg
In a few frantic days, the West abandoned traditional tactics and instead isolated Russia with unparalleled sanctions and penalties. Here's how it happened. https://t.co/nSVYQ6Fqva

Berlin has become a major hub for refugees from Ukraine, welcoming them with an outpouring of help. The response stirs memories of both bright and dark chapters of German history. https://t.co/ChI980IWcY

Kherson, in southern Ukraine, was the first major city to fall to Russian forces. On Saturday, street protests presented a challenge to the new authority there. Here's what one of our reporters in Ukraine saw on the ground. https://t.co/BfdKOcXidT

Senior U.S. officials are traveling to Venezuela on Saturday to meet with the government of President Nicolás Maduro as the Biden administration steps up efforts to separate Russia from its remaining allies amid a widening standoff over Ukraine. https://t.co/3SsZX3qTaI

Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, said Saturday that it would continue to buy Russian crude oil to feed into its refineries and supply customers with gasoline and diesel but would donate any profits to a fund dedicated to “the people of Ukraine.” https://t.co/QBNCs6aKEP

Mastercard and Visa announced on Saturday that they would suspend operations in Russia, essentially severing cardholders there from transactions outside the country in response to the invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/1dU8GfAxwy
Videos verified by The New York Times appear to show Russian-backed separatists in a small town in eastern Ukraine firing on protesters, striking one in the leg. https://t.co/paZ4nDtdWF

While technology giants like Apple and luxury retailers like Hermès have quickly moved to pause sales or shutter stores in Russia over the invasion of Ukraine, fast-food chains like McDonald’s and Yum Brands have remained open — and largely silent. https://t.co/6bNBftdyST

Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said that the Biden administration has asked Congress to approve $2.75 billion in humanitarian assistance for vulnerable communities inside Ukraine and refugee services in neighboring countries. https://t.co/m66ls7GKXw https://t.co/JcPicZ2N9X

In Opinion
"In just over one week of hellish war, Ukrainians revealed themselves to be some of the bravest people in the world," writes Anastasiia Lapatina, a Ukrainian reporter at The Kyiv Independent. "We will not surrender and we will not capitulate." https://t.co/DyLSdWxWXb

People from the city of Irpin rushed to Kyiv’s central railway station on Friday to flee heavy fighting. "It's terrible and terrifying," one resident said in tears. "We have to leave our relatives, our father, our brother and, just for what?" https://t.co/GFJta7wGO4 https://t.co/ko9pHMIaz0

Oleksandr Abramenko, the Ukrainian skier whose hug with a Russian rival at the Beijing Olympics was widely shared, has been sleeping in a Kyiv garage for several days now with his wife and 2-year-old son. "The air attack siren is constantly on," he said. https://t.co/gidPH4S8jF

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spoke with U.S. Congress members via Zoom on Saturday, asking them for more jets and again asking for a no-fly zone over his country, which Western governments have rebuffed as all but impossible. https://t.co/zzc6LqDGPH

Allied nations are discussing how to secure Ukraine's line of succession if President Volodymyr Zelensky is captured or killed. The concerns are primarily about ensuring an independent government of some form, even if Russia installs puppet leadership. https://t.co/BvafNkveep

Some U.S. veterans are looking to join the fight in Ukraine, emboldened by President Volodymyr Zelensky's call for volunteers, though the U.S. has long discouraged its citizens from becoming freelance fighters because of the risk of unintended escalation. https://t.co/OVDawElcBR

In Opinion
“As Russia’s leader holds his ground, increasingly isolated from the rest of the world, the leadership of the United States and its European allies becomes ever more essential,” writes the editorial board. https://t.co/moBrmeR7GI

Protesters have gathered in Kherson, the first major Ukrainian city to fall to Russian forces. One video verified by The New York Times shows a man waving a Ukrainian flag on top of a Russian armored personnel carrier, prompting cheers from onlookers. https://t.co/rIV6HbxT7p

Breaking News: Russian customs officials said they had detained a star American basketball player after finding hashish oil in her luggage at an airport near Moscow. The Russian news agency TASS has identified the player as Brittney Griner. https://t.co/7rJaQqNyJK

Oleksandr Abramenko, the Ukrainian skiier whose hug with a Russian rival at the Beijing Olympics was widely shared, has been sleeping in a Kyiv garage for several days now with his wife and 2-year-old son. "The air attack siren is constantly on," he said. https://t.co/obxbOl73QE

President Vladimir Putin of Russia said on Saturday that Ukraine might lose its statehood in his first extended remarks since the start of the war. "If that happens, they will have to be blamed for that," he said.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/w1EEaYQZqg

"We have no choice."
At a station in Western Ukraine, mothers and their children boarded evacuation trains to Poland, while many of their husbands stayed to defend Ukraine from advancing Russian forces. https://t.co/4Z5NTCsRtL

Breaking News: President Vladimir Putin likened Western sanctions on Russia to a "declaration of war" and threatened Ukraine with loss of its statehood if its leaders continued to resist his military invasion.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/EcRBCIaSdq
Apparent volunteers have stormed Russia and Ukraine with cyberattacks, blurring the lines between state-backed hackers and patriotic amateurs. https://t.co/2raXZSHc5B

The BBC said on Friday that it was temporarily suspending its operations in Russia after the country’s parliament passed a censorship law that penalizes anyone deemed to be “discrediting” the Russian military with 15 years in prison. https://t.co/mjs0P4K0tT
White House officials say they are debating a new concern: As sanctions isolate Russia, will President Vladimir Putin lash out beyond Ukraine? https://t.co/Wb4sHpd1VB

News Analysis: The multinational response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine shows that liberalism has some life left. But the challenges posed by waning U.S. power and rising authoritarianism remain formidable. https://t.co/z0xDpIks2q

NATO officials on Friday accused Russia of using cluster bombs in its invasion of Ukraine but rejected Kyiv’s plea to impose a no-fly zone over Ukrainian airspace, fearing that would draw the military alliance into a larger war with Russia. https://t.co/i3AuJ83BXE

The UN Human Rights Council voted to set up a commission of inquiry to look into possible war crimes and human rights violations in Ukraine, adding impetus to global efforts to ensure Russia is held liable for its invasion and any abuses related to it. https://t.co/vAserjTcDY

As they impose sanctions on Russia, the Biden administration and European governments set new goals: devastate the Russian economy as punishment for the world to witness, and create domestic pressure on President Vladimir Putin to halt his war in Ukraine. https://t.co/Ax1fXOevrB

Microsoft said on Friday that it would suspend new sales of its products and services in Russia, becoming the latest in a growing list of Western companies to reconsider their ties to the country after its invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/h6IsGgyFB1

The president of the International Paralympic Committee broke protocol in his speech at the opening ceremony of the Beijing Games on Friday, saying he was “horrified” by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/J6YOKRcYXv

President Vladimir Putin of Russia “must stop this madness, and stop it now,” the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, told the Security Council on Friday.
Follow our live updates: https://t.co/qZ6N3M57Ux https://t.co/LBOn8k9Lv4
Breaking News: Tesla won approval to begin production at its first major assembly plant in Europe, near Berlin. The company plans to build 500,000 electric cars a year there. https://t.co/wXVk05sN4q

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine criticized NATO late Friday night over its rejection of a no-fly zone, hours after the alliance announced it would not intervene by air or land for fear of creating a broader conflict with Russia. https://t.co/M5UYJcnewd

Switzerland targeted Russia with sweeping financial and business sanctions on Friday over its invasion of Ukraine. The new measures were in addition to sanctions announced four days ago that broke with the country’s long tradition of neutrality. https://t.co/2ULjngTvtF

New York City is home to an estimated 300,000 Jewish immigrants from the former Soviet Union, and the largest single group of them are from Ukraine. Many have become part of a robust fund-raising effort, which has produced millions in humanitarian aid. https://t.co/zuY0gpy5fu

Javelin antitank missiles, rocket launchers, guns and ammunition were transported to an airfield near Ukraine’s border, as the U.S. and European allies ramped up efforts to give the Ukrainian military a leg up in battling a foreign enemy that outguns it. https://t.co/xis3gV5duo

The founder of America’s Frontline Doctors, an activist group known for spreading misinformation about the pandemic and Covid vaccines, has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge related to the storming of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 last year. https://t.co/H4ssq1RR0X

Hundreds of Ukrainian mothers waited anxiously with their children on Thursday to board trains bound for Poland. “We have to save our children,” one mother said. https://t.co/qOJeJtyI8F https://t.co/thJ21mXLZg
The BBC and Bloomberg News are suspending reporting in Russia after the country’s new free-speech crackdown. CNN said it stopped airing there. https://t.co/T9db3gZmGx

President Volodymyr Zelensky urged Europeans on Friday to “take to the streets” to support Ukraine. Protesters did so in Bratislava, Frankfurt, Lyon, Prague, Tbilisi, Vienna and Vilnius.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/IQ5B32Kuhf https://t.co/JVLLZqfnU4

The French luxury giants LVMH and Hermès each said Friday that they would temporarily close their stores in Russia, joining several Western retailers like Ikea, H&M Group and Nike that have made similar announcements in recent days. https://t.co/0nd1P5YMSY

A major U.S. internet service provider said it would end its relationships with Russian internet companies, a move that could disrupt some service in Russia and further its isolation from the rest of the world. https://t.co/orOVjywIsG

Mayor Eric Adams ended New York City’s mask mandate for public schools and a proof-of-vaccination requirement for indoor dining, gyms and entertainment venues. "It’s time to reopen our city," he said. https://t.co/SHRtTv5C9O

Senator Lindsey Graham on Thursday said somebody in Russia should “step up to the plate” and “take this guy out,” referring to President Vladimir Putin. Graham faced swift backlash from fellow Republicans. https://t.co/TJcMo0SZ6G
Shane Warne, one of the greatest cricket players of all time, and a larger-than-life figure on and off the field, died Friday in Thailand. He was 52. https://t.co/YI69MS2WGz https://t.co/PoWaJzaGHm

Russia passed a law Friday punishing the spreading of "false information" about Russia’s forces with as much as 15 years in prison. The law could make a criminal offense of simply calling the war a "war" and will take effect as soon as Saturday. https://t.co/y2EwoNyeOd
Videos verified by The New York Times reveal the scale of the devastation of civilian areas in Kharkiv, Ukraine, after days of Russian bombardment. https://t.co/WeeERIFiI4
Breaking News: Hiring in the U.S. sped up in February, with employers adding 678,000 jobs, as falling Covid cases brought customers and workers back. https://t.co/dgGKj7UZM4
